37. Effect: Absorption¶

class optcom.effects.absorption.Absorption(dopant='yt', predict=None)¶

Generic class for effect object.

omega¶

The angular frequency array. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

time¶

The time array. \([ps]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

center_omega¶

The center angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

Parameters

  • dopant (str) -- The doping agent.

  • predict (Optional[Callable]) -- A callable object to predict the cross sections. The variable must be the wavelength. \([nm]\)

static calc_cross_section(omega, dopant='Yb', predict=None)¶

Calculate the absorption cross section. Calculate with the fitting formula from ref. 4 .

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • dopant -- The doping agent.

  • predict -- A callable object to predict the cross sections. The variable must be the wavelength. \([nm]\)

Returns

Value of the absorption cross section. \([nm^2]\)

Return type

float or numpy.ndarray of float

Notes

Considering:

\[f(\lambda, \lambda_c, \lambda_w, n) = \exp\Big[-\Big\lvert \frac{\lambda-\lambda_c}{\lambda_w}\Big\rvert^n \Big]\]

With \(\lambda\), \(\lambda_c\) and \(\lambda_w\) in \([nm]\)

For Ytterbium:

\[\sigma_a^{Yb}(\lambda) = 0.09f(\lambda,913,8,2) + 0.13 f(\lambda,950,40,4) + 0.2 f(\lambda, 968, 40, 2.4) + 1.08 f(\lambda, 975.8,3,1.5)\]

For Erbium:

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} \sigma_a^{Er}(\lambda) &= 0.221 f(\lambda, 1493, 16.5, 2.2) + 0.342 f(\lambda, 1534, 4.5, 1.4)\\ &\quad + 0.158f(\lambda, 1534, 30,4) + 0.037 f(\lambda, 1534, 85, 4) + 0.132 f(\lambda, 1541, 8,0.8) \end{split}\end{split}\]

References

4

Valley, G.C., 2001. Modeling cladding-pumped Er/Yb fiber amplifiers. Optical Fiber Technology, 7(1), pp.21-44.

Type

time¶

The time array. \([ps]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

center_omega¶

The center angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

Parameters

  • delta (Optional[float]) -- The asymmetry measure coefficient. If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • beta_01 (Union[float, Callable, None]) -- The zeroth order Taylor series dispersion coefficient of first waveguide. \([km^{-1}]\)

  • beta_02 (Union[float, Callable, None]) -- The zeroth order Taylor series dispersion coefficient of second waveguide. \([km^{-1}]\)

  • medium (str) -- The medium in which the dispersion is considered.

static calc_delta(beta_01, beta_02)¶

Calculate the measure of asymmetry for the parameters given for two waveguides. 8

Parameters

  • beta_01 -- The first term of the propagation constant of the first waveguide. \([km^{-1}]\)

  • beta_02 -- The first term of the propagation constant of the second waveguide. \([km^{-1}]\)

Returns

Value of the asymmetry measure. \([km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\delta_{a12} = \frac{1}{2} (\beta_{01} - \beta_{02})\]

References

43. Effect: Coupling¶

class optcom.effects.coupling.Coupling(kappa=None, V=2.0, a=5.0, d=15.0, n_0=1.0)¶

Generic class for effect object.

omega¶

The angular frequency array. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

time¶

The time array. \([ps]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

center_omega¶

The center angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

Parameters

  • kappa (Optional[List[float]]) -- The coupling coefficients. \([km^{-1}]\)

  • V (float) -- The fiber parameter.

  • a (float) -- The core radius. \([\mu m]\)

  • d (float) -- The center to center spacing between the two cores. \([\mu m]\)

  • n_0 (float) -- The refractive index outside of the two fiber cores.

static calc_kappa(omega, V=2.0, a=5.0, d=15.0, n_0=1.0)¶

Calculate the coupling coefficient for the parameters given for two waveguides. (assuming the two waveguides are symmetric) 7

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • V -- The fiber parameter.

  • a -- The core radius. \([\mu m]\)

  • d -- The center to center spacing between the two cores. \([\mu m]\)

  • n_0 -- The refractive index outside of the two fiber cores.

Returns

Value of the coupling coefficient. \([km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\kappa = \frac{\pi V}{2 k_0 n_0 a^2} e^{-(c_0 + c_1 d + c_2 d^2)}\]

This equation is accurate to within 1% for values of the fiber parameter \(1.5\leq V\leq 2.5\) and of the normalized center-to-center spacing \(\bar{d} = d/a\), \(2\leq \bar{d}\leq 4.5\) .

References

7

Govind Agrawal, Chapter 2: Fibers Couplers, Applications of Nonlinear Fiber Optics (Second Edition), Academic Press, 2008, Page 59.

op(waves, id, corr_wave=None)¶

The operator of the dispersion effect.

Return type

Array

term(waves, id, corr_wave=None)¶

The term of the effect.

Parameters

  • waves (Array) -- The wave packet.

  • id (int) -- The ID of the considered wave in the wave packet.

  • corr_wave (Optional[Array]) -- Corrective wave, optional, used if needed.

Return type

Array

Returns

The term of the effect.

44. Effect: Dispersion¶

class optcom.effects.dispersion.Dispersion(beta=None, order=2, medium='sio2', start_taylor=2)¶

Generic class for effect object.

omega¶

The angular frequency array. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

time¶

The time array. \([ps]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

center_omega¶

The center angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

Parameters

  • beta (Union[List[float], Callable, None]) -- The derivatives of the propagation constant. \([km^{-1}, ps\cdot km^{-1}, ps^2\cdot km^{-1}, ps^3\cdot km^{-1}, \ldots]\) If a callable is provided, variable must be angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • order (int) -- The order of beta coefficients to take into account. (will be ignored if beta values are provided - no file)

  • medium (str) -- The medium in which the dispersion is considered.

  • start_taylor (int) -- The order of the derivative from which to start the Taylor Series expansion.

static calc_RDS(Lambda, beta_2, beta_3)¶

Calculate the relative dispersion slope.

Parameters

  • Lambda -- The wavelength. \([nm]\)

  • beta_2 -- The GVD term of the dispersion. \([ps^2\cdot km^{-1}]\)

  • beta_3 -- The third order dispersion term. \([ps^3\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Returns

Value of the dispersion parameter. \([nm^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[RDS = \frac{S}{D}\]
static calc_accumulated_dispersion(Lambda, beta_2, length)¶

Calculate the dispersion parameter.

Parameters

  • Lambda -- The wavelength. \([nm]\)

  • beta_2 -- The GVD term of the dispersion. \([ps^2\cdot km^{-1}]\)

  • length -- The length over which dispersion is considered. \([km]\)

Returns

Value of the dispersion parameter. \([ps \cdot nm^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[D_{acc} = D \cdot L\]
static calc_beta(omega, medium, n=None)¶

Calcul the propagation constant. (valid only for TEM)

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • medium -- The medium in which the wave propagates (used for Sellmeier equations if n not provided).

  • n -- The refractive index at angular frequency \(\omega\). Calcul \(n(\omega)\) from Sellmeier equation if None.

Returns

The propagation constant. \([km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\beta(\omega) = k(\omega) = k_0 n(\omega) = \frac{\omega}{c} n(\omega)\]
static calc_beta_coeffs(omega, order, class_n)¶

Calcul the nth first derivatives of the propagation constant. (valid only for TEM)

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • order -- The order of the highest dispersion coefficient.

  • class_n (AbstractRefractiveIndex) -- A function which calculate the refractive index.

Returns

The nth derivative of the propagation constant. \([ps^{i}\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\beta_i(\omega) = \frac{d^i \beta(\omega)}{d\omega^i} = \frac{1}{c}\bigg(i \frac{d^{(i-1)} n(\omega)}{d\omega^{(i-1)}} + \omega \frac{d^i n(\omega)}{d\omega^i}\bigg)\]

for \(i = 0, \ldots, \text{order}\)

static calc_beta_deriv(omega, order, medium)¶

Calcul the nth derivative of the propagation constant. (valid only for TEM)

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • order -- The order of the derivative.

  • medium -- The medium in which the wave propagates, used for Sellmeier equations in order to calculate the refractive index.

Returns

The nth derivative of the propagation constant. \([ps^{i}\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\beta_i(\omega) = \frac{d^i \beta(\omega)}{d\omega^i} = \frac{1}{c}\bigg(i \frac{d^{(i-1)} n(\omega)}{d\omega^{(i-1)}} + \omega \frac{d^i n(\omega)}{d\omega^i}\bigg)\]

for \(i = 0, \ldots, \text{order}\)

static calc_dispersion(Lambda, beta_2)¶

Calculate the dispersion parameter.

Parameters

  • Lambda -- The wavelength. \([nm]\)

  • beta_2 -- The GVD term of the dispersion. \([ps^2\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Returns

Value of the dispersion parameter. \([ps \cdot nm^{-1} \cdot km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[D = \frac{d}{d\lambda}\Big(\frac{1}{v_g}\Big) = \frac{d}{d\lambda} \beta_1 = -\frac{2\pi c}{\lambda^2} \beta_2\]
static calc_dispersion_length(width, beta_2)¶

Calculate dispersion length.

Parameters

  • width -- The power. \([ps]\)

  • beta_2 -- The GVD term of the dispersion. \([ps^2\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Returns

The dispersion length \([km]\)

Notes

\[L_{D} = \frac{T_0^2}{|\beta_2|}\]
static calc_dispersion_slope(Lambda, beta_2, beta_3)¶

Calculate the dispersio slope.

Parameters

  • Lambda -- The wavelength. \([nm]\)

  • beta_2 -- The GVD term of the dispersion. \([ps^2\cdot km^{-1}]\)

  • beta_3 -- The third order dispersion term. \([ps^3\cdot km^{-1}]\)

Returns

Value of the dispersion parameter. \([ps \cdot nm^{-2} \cdot km^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[S = \frac{d D}{d\lambda} = \beta_2 \frac{d}{d\lambda} \Big(-\frac{2\pi c} {\lambda^2}\Big) - \frac{2\pi c} {\lambda^2} \frac{d\beta_2}{d\lambda} = \frac{4\pi c}{\lambda^3} \beta_2 + \Big(\frac{2\pi c}{\lambda^2}\Big)^2 \beta_3\]
op(waves, id, corr_wave=None)¶

The operator of the dispersion effect.

Return type

Array

48. Effect: Raman Scattering¶

class optcom.effects.raman.Raman(T_R=0.003, eta=2.0, approx_type=1, cross_term=False, tau_1=0.0122, tau_2=0.032, tau_b=0.096, f_a=0.75, f_b=0.21, f_c=0.04, h_R=None, time=None, omega=None)¶

Generic class for effect object.

omega¶

The angular frequency array. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

time¶

The time array. \([ps]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

center_omega¶

The center angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

Parameters

  • T_R (float) -- The raman coefficient. \([]\)

  • eta (float) -- Positive term multiplying the cross terms in the effect.

  • approx_type (int) -- The type of the NLSE approximation.

  • cross_term (bool) -- If True, trigger the cross-term influence in the effect.

  • tau_1 (float) -- The inverse of vibrational frequency of the fiber core molecules. \([ps]\)

  • tau_2 (float) -- The damping time of vibrations. \([ps]\)

  • tau_b (float) -- The spectral width of the Boson peak. \([ps]\)

  • f_a (float) -- The fractional contribution of the isotropic part to the isotropic Raman function.

  • f_b (float) -- The fractional contribution of the anisotropic part to the anisotropic Raman function.

  • f_c (float) -- The fractional contributian of the isotropic part to the anisotropic Raman function.

  • h_R (Optional[Array]) -- The Raman response function values.

  • time (Optional[Array]) -- The time values of the field.

  • omega (Optional[Array]) -- The angular frequencies values of the field.

static calc_h_R(time, tau_1=0.0122, tau_2=0.032, tau_b=0.096, f_a=0.75, f_b=0.21, f_c=0.04)¶

Calculate the Raman response function as the sum of the isotropic \(R_a(t)\) and anisotropic \(R_b(t)\) (Boson peak) Raman response functions. 1

Parameters

  • time (Array) -- The time value(s). \([ps]\)

  • tau_1 (float) -- The inverse of vibrational frequency of the fiber core molecules. \([ps]\)

  • tau_2 (float) -- The damping time of vibrations. \([ps]\)

  • tau_b (float) -- The spectral width of the Boson peak. \([ps]\)

  • f_a (float) -- The fractional contribution of the isotropic part to the isotropic Raman function.

  • f_b (float) -- The fractional contribution of the anisotropic part to the anisotropic Raman function.

  • f_c (float) -- The fractional contributian of the isotropic part to the anisotropic Raman function.

Return type

Array

Returns

Value of the Raman response function at the time given as parameter. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[\begin{split}\begin{split} h_R(t) &= R_a(t) + R_b(t)\\ &= (f_a h_a(t)) + (f_b h_b(t) + f_c h_a(t))\\ &= (f_a+f_c)h_a(t) + f_b h_b(t) \end{split}\end{split}\]

References

1

Lin, Q. and Agrawal, G.P., 2006. Raman response function for silica fibers. Optics letters, 31(21), pp.3086-3088.

static calc_h_a(time, tau_1=0.0122, tau_2=0.032)¶

Calculate the isotropic part of the Raman response function. 2

Parameters

  • time (Array) -- The time value(s). \([ps]\)

  • tau_1 (float) -- The inverse of vibrational frequency of the fiber core molecules. \([ps]\)

  • tau_2 (float) -- The damping time of vibrations. \([ps]\)

Return type

Array

Returns

Value of the isotropic part of the Raman response function at the time given as parameter. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[h_a(t) = \frac{\tau_1}{\tau_1^2 + \tau_2^2} e^{\frac{-t}{\tau_2}} \sin\big(\frac{t}{\tau_1}\big)\]

References

2

Lin, Q. and Agrawal, G.P., 2006. Raman response function for silica fibers. Optics letters, 31(21), pp.3086-3088.

static calc_h_b(time, tau_b=0.096)¶

Calculate the anisotropic part (boson peak) of the Raman response function. 3

Parameters

  • time (Array) -- The time value(s). \([ps]\)

  • tau_b (float) -- The spectral width of the Boson peak. \([ps]\)

Return type

Array

Returns

Value of the anisotropic part of the Raman response function at the time given as parameter. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Notes

\[h_b(t) = \frac{2\tau_b - t}{\tau_b^2} e^{\frac{-t}{\tau_b}}\]

References

3

Lin, Q. and Agrawal, G.P., 2006. Raman response function for silica fibers. Optics letters, 31(21), pp.3086-3088.

static calc_raman_gain(omega_bw, h_R, center_omega, n_0, f_R, n_2)¶

Calculate the Raman gain.

Parameters

  • omega_bw (float) -- The angular frequency bandwidth. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • h_R (Array) -- The raman response function. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • center_omega (float) -- The center angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

  • n_0 (float) -- The refractive index.

  • f_R (float) -- The fractional contribution of the delayed Raman response. \([]\)

  • n_2 (float) -- The non-linear index. \([m^2\cdot W^{-1}]\)

Return type

Array

Returns

The Raman gain.

Notes

\[g_R(\Delta \omega) = \frac{\omega_0}{c n_0} f_R \chi^{(3)} \Im{\hat{h}_R(\Delta \omega)}\]

where:

\[\chi^{(3)} = \frac{4\epsilon_0 c n^2}{3} n_2\]

\(\chi^{(3)}\) is in \([m^2 \cdot V^{-2}]\).

op(waves, id, corr_wave=None)¶

The non approximated operator of the Raman effect.

Return type

Array

op_approx(waves, id, corr_wave=None)¶

The approximation of the operator of the Raman effect.

Return type

Array

op_approx_cross(waves, id, corr_wave=None)¶

The approximation operator of the cross terms of the Raman effect.

Return type

Array

op_approx_self(waves, id, corr_wave=None)¶

The approximation of the operator of the Raman effect for the considered wave.

Return type

Array

51. Effect: Stimulated emission¶

class optcom.effects.stimulated_emission.StimulatedEmission(dopant='yt', predict=None)¶

Generic class for effect object.

omega¶

The angular frequency array. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

time¶

The time array. \([ps]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

center_omega¶

The center angular frequency. \([ps^{-1}]\)

Type

numpy.ndarray of float

Parameters

  • dopant (str) -- The doping agent.

  • predict (Optional[Callable]) -- A callable object to predict the cross sections. The variable must be the wavelength. \([nm]\)

static calc_cross_section(omega, dopant='Yb', predict=None, center_omega=None, N_0=None, N_1=None, T=None)¶

Calculate the emission cross section. There is no analytical formula for the emission cross section. Calculate first the absorption cross sections with the fitting formula from ref. 5 and then use the McCumber relations to deduce the emission cross sections.

Parameters

  • omega -- The angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • dopant -- The type of the doped medium.

  • predict -- A callable object to predict the cross sections. The variable must be the wavelength. \([nm]\)

  • center_omega -- The center angular frequency. \([rad\cdot ps^{-1}]\)

  • N_0 -- The population in ground state. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • N_1 -- The population in the excited state. \([nm^{-3}]\)

  • T -- The temperature. \([K]\)

Returns

Value of the emission cross section. \([nm^2]\)

References

5

Valley, G.C., 2001. Modeling cladding-pumped Er/Yb fiber amplifiers. Optical Fiber Technology, 7(1), pp.21-44.
